Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, § 19 given that the claimed damages fall within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this district pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Worcester County.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 85, \u00a7 5..proposition: The Defendant, Emily Rodriguez, as the owner of the Property, has a duty to maintain the sidewalk adjoining the Property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors and members of the public, including tenants, guests, and delivery personnel, pursuant to Massachusetts common law and Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 85, § 5.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law, as established in *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (holding property owners owe a duty to lawful visitors to remedy hazards caused by snow and ice accumulation); *Osornio v. Reardon*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 115 (2004) (confirming liability for injury caused by failure to address icy conditions on property).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos directly holds that Massachusetts property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards arising from snow and ice, abolishing the prior ‘natural vs. unnatural accumulation’ limitation. The court states that hazards from snow and ice are subject to the same reasonable-care duty as all other premises hazards, which is exactly the duty proposition the citation is being used to support (that a failure to address dangerous snow/ice conditions can constitute negligence under Massachusetts law). The additional reference to Osornio is not in this opinion but does not affect Papadopoulos’s clear support for the stated rule.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Osornio v. Reardon*, 62 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law, as established in *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (holding property owners owe a duty to lawful visitors to remedy hazards caused by snow and ice accumulation); *Osornio v. Reardon*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 115 (2004) (confirming liability for injury caused by failure to address icy conditions on property).
*Osornio v. Reardon*, 62 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Osornio v. Reardon is not a premises-liability or snow-and-ice case; it concerns the imposition of Rule 11 sanctions on an attorney for bad‑faith litigation conduct. The opinion does not discuss a landowner’s duty regarding icy conditions, negligence standards for snow and ice, or liability for injuries caused by failure to remedy such conditions. Using Osornio as authority for negligence arising from icy-property conditions misstates the holding and context of the decision.
*Osornio v. Reardon*, 62 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "We consider the appeal of the plaintiffs’ attorney, Edwin A. McCabe, from an order of a judge of the Superior Court directing that he pay, as a sanction under Mass.R.Civ.P. 11(a)... We conclude that the imposition of sanctions in the circumstances was entirely justified, and we affirm the order."

*Klerman v. Fine*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 100.proposition: Defendant’s failure to properly maintain the sidewalk and respond to complaints of hazardous conditions demonstrates a breach of the standard of care outlined in Massachusetts case law, including *Klerman v. Fine*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1003 (2000) and *Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc.*, 418 Mass. 590 (1994).

*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.proposition: Defendant’s failure to properly maintain the sidewalk and respond to complaints of hazardous conditions demonstrates a breach of the standard of care outlined in Massachusetts case law, including *Klerman v. Fine*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1003 (2000) and *Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc.*, 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.support_reasoning: Barry does not hold that a defendant’s failure to properly maintain the sidewalk and respond to hazardous conditions constituted a breach. Instead, the SJC reverses a plaintiff’s verdict and orders judgment notwithstanding the verdict because the evidence was insufficient to show the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition. The case emphasizes the need for actual or constructive notice and concludes that, on the facts presented, the defendant did not violate its duty of reasonable care.
*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.relevant_excerpt: “After reviewing the evidence presented at the first trial, we conclude that the defendant’s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict should have been allowed because the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, was not sufficient to warrant an inference that the defendant violated the duty of reasonable care that it owed to the plaintiff. … [T]he evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, \u00a7 1 (liabi.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, § 1 (liability for maintaining unreasonable hazards on property)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, \u00a7 1 (liabi.proposition: Massachusetts statutory and case law further support Plaintiff’s claim, including Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, § 1 (liability for maintaining unreasonable hazards on property) and *Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc.*, 414 Mass. 60 (1992).

*Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc.*, 414 M.proposition: Massachusetts statutory and case law further support Plaintiff’s claim, including Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, § 1 (liability for maintaining unreasonable hazards on property) and *Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc.*, 414 Mass. 60 (1992).
*Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc.*, 414 M.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc. at all, but a criminal case concerning jury empanelment and related procedural issues. It does not discuss Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 242, § 1, property conditions, or liability for maintaining unreasonable hazards on land. Therefore, as presented, this case cannot support the stated proposition about statutory premises liability or unreasonable hazards on property.
*Sylvia v. Belmont Springs, Inc.*, 414 M.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 234, § 28 (1990 ed.), requires a judge, on ‘motion of either party . . . [to] examine on oath a person who is called as a juror therein, to learn whether he . . . has expressed or formed an opinion, or is sensible of any bias or prejudice’ toward a defendant or in a case.”
